title: Adding frontend-specific fields to Field List documentation

content.raw:
Maybe just use the literal `particle_type` for all the `known_particle_fields` in the SPH frontends?  For example: `(particle_type, 'Density')`. 

You could also just load datasets from some of the frontends and iterate through `ds.field_list`, perhaps taking the set intersection of the fields known by the various particle types.  This would of course miss fields that aren't in the dataset you choose to use.

If you're OK with it, I'm happy to implement one of these suggestions tonight so we can get this done.
content.html:
Maybe just use the literal particle_type for all the known_particle_fields in the SPH frontends? For example: (particle_type, 'Density').

You could also just load datasets from some of the frontends and iterate through ds.field_list, perhaps taking the set intersection of the fields known by the various particle types. This would of course miss fields that aren't in the dataset you choose to use.

If you're OK with it, I'm happy to implement one of these suggestions tonight so we can get this done.

pullrequest.title: Adding frontend-specific fields to Field List documentation

content.raw:
This may be clearer if we provide full field names:

"frontend, the ``dens`` field (i.e. (``flash``, ``dens``)) is aliased to the ``gas`` field ``density`` (i.e. (``gas``, ``density``)), similarly (``flash``, ``velx``) is aliased to
(``gas``, ``velocity_x``), and so on. In what follows, if a field is aliased it will be noted.
content.html:
This may be clearer if we provide full field names:

"frontend, the dens field (i.e. (flash, dens)) is aliased to the gas field density (i.e. (gas, density)), similarly (flash, velx) is aliased to (gas, velocity_x), and so on. In what follows, if a field is aliased it will be noted.

pullrequest.title: Adding frontend-specific fields to Field List documentation

content.raw:
@jzuhone and @ngoldbaum (and @MatthewTurk), this is excellent.  I think this is a great step forward and will help users new and old figure out what the heck is going on with fields as we move to 3.0.  I only have a few comments that I've listed below.  

Instead of having the frontend-specific headings with +++++, and the fields as -----, could we do frontend-specific headings as ----- and fields as ^^^^^?  I find it easier to parse this way because +++ and --- are about the same size font.

Also, we list 'io' and 'all' fields in the "fields generated by yt", but these will only be generated for some frontends, right?  This isn't a huge deal, but I thought it was worth mentioning.  I guess it is specific to the dataset used.

I also marked one other nit below, which I think might help clarify things for the new field system.  Other than that, this looks great!  Thank you!
content.html:
John ZuHone and Nathan Goldbaum (and Matt Turk), this is excellent. I think this is a great step forward and will help users new and old figure out what the heck is going on with fields as we move to 3.0. I only have a few comments that I've listed below.

Instead of having the frontend-specific headings with +++++, and the fields as -----, could we do frontend-specific headings as ----- and fields as ^^^^^? I find it easier to parse this way because +++ and --- are about the same size font.

Also, we list 'io' and 'all' fields in the "fields generated by yt", but these will only be generated for some frontends, right? This isn't a huge deal, but I thought it was worth mentioning. I guess it is specific to the dataset used.

I also marked one other nit below, which I think might help clarify things for the new field system. Other than that, this looks great! Thank you!

pullrequest.title: Adding frontend-specific fields to Field List documentation

description:
This allows the known fields for each frontend to be added to the Field List documentation. What this does it parse the available frontends, check the ``known_other_fields`` and ``known_particle_fields`` tuples for each, and then list these fields, including their units, particle type, and if they are aliased. 

This has a couple of issues that need to be worked out before this PR is accepted. 

1) This simply doesn't work for SPH fields. The various SPH frontends assign ``ftype``s depending on the frontend, which doesn't happen unless you have a ``Dataset`` loaded into memory. 

2) Similarly, I can't figure out how to do this for particle fields in other frontends, since they have different ``ftype``s depending on the different particle types, unless there is only one particle type, in which case ``ftype`` == ``"io"``. 

So, we need to sort out how to handle these problems before we accept this.
